user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_nonce_timestamp:
```c
static bool
get_nonce_timestamp (const char *const nonce,
                     size_t noncelen,
                     uint64_t *const ptimestamp)
{
  if (0 == noncelen)
    noncelen = strlen (nonce);

  if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;

  if (TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN !=
      MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             ptimestamp))
    return false;
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function get_nonce_timestamp:
#define MD5_DIGEST_SIZE (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE_WORDS*MD5_BYTES_IN_WORD)
...
#define SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE
...
#define MHD_MD5_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT 1
...
#define TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN (TIMESTAMP_BIN_SIZE*2)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only parameter that is modified in this function is the noncelen parameter; both the declaration (size_t noncelen) and the assignment that changes it should be investigated for potential noncompliance with MISRA C Rule 17.8. Other fragments do not need investigation for this rule: the nonce parameter is declared as const char *const (the pointer and the pointed-to data are const) so it is not modified; ptimestamp is declared as uint64_t *const (the pointer itself is const) and only the object it points to may be modified via the helper function MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_, which is permitted by the rule; the remaining conditional checks, return statements, and size comparisons do not modify function parameters and therefore are not relevant to Rule 17.8.
